Award.AwardTitle: WOU-MMA: Probing Supermassive Binary Black Holes with Pulsar Timing Arrays
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research in relativity and relativistic astrophysics and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. Gravitational waves provide a new way of observing the Universe and promise to revolutionize our understanding of many topics in physics and astronomy. Pulsar timing arrays (PTAs) use millisecond pulsars to detect low-frequency gravitational waves, and promising sources in this frequency band include supermassive binary black holes. Gravitational wave observations of these sources will help us understand their growth and evolution, as well as the properties of the galaxies in which they reside. PTAs can also perform fundamental tests of gravity by determining whether the gravitational waves emitted by these sources have the properties predicted by general relativity.

The research in this proposal focuses on developing data analysis techniques for PTAs. The PI will use simulations to study how the significance of the gravitational wave signal evolves over time, and use these results to design robust pipelines for detecting and characterizing gravitational waves. The PI will also study ways of optimizing pulsar timing arrays, such as identifying sky locations to search for new millisecond pulsars. Finally, the PI will improve methods for combining data from different telescopes to enhance the sensitivity of PTAs by leveraging the next-generation radio telescopes currently under construction around the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gravittational waves are ripples in spacetime generated by the acceleration of massive objects, such as black holes. Observations of gravitational waves can be used to study the objects that produce them. Pulsar timing arrays are sensitive to low-frequency gravitational waves with periods of months to decades, such as those produced by supermassive binary black holes, and is complementary of gravitational-wave interferometers such as the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO), which are sensitive to high-frequency gravitational waves.

Supermassive black holes live at the centers of massive galaxies, and their properties are tied to those of their host galaxies. Galaxies evolve through a series of mergers, and when two massive galaxies merge, their supermassive black holes form a binary. When they reach subparsec separations, they emit gravitational waves that can be detected by pulsar timing arrays. Observing gravitational waves from these sources can help us understand the population of supermassive black holes, their environments, and the rate of galaxy mergers.

This award supported the developpment of methods to detect gravitational waves with pulsar timing arrays, and studies to determine optimal observing strategies to detect gravitational waves from individual supermassive binary black holes.

Develop methods for detecting and characterizing the gravitational wave background. The population of supermassive binary black holes generates a "hum" of gravitational waves known as the gravitational wave background. The gravitational wave background induces correlations in the timing residuals between different pulsars that follows a characteristic pattern known as the Hellings-Downs curve. But other astrophysical and terrestrial effects can also induce correlations between pulsars, albeit with a different pattern. We developed the multiple correlation optimal statistic (MCOS) to characterize the correlations between pulsars and simultaneously search for multiple correlated processes. We also studied how the number of pulsars affects gravitational wave searches, and showed that using a large number of pulsars produces more robust results. Finally, we developed a new pipeline to search for the gravitational wave background that uses Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. As pulsar timing arrays add more pulsars, gravitational wave searches become more computationally expensive, and we demonstrated that Hamiltonian Monte Carlo can perform these searches more efficiently.

Develop methods for detecting individual supermassive binary black holes. In addition to the gravitational wave background, pulsar timing arrays can observe nearby supermassive binary black holes as individual sources. Some supermassive binary black holes may be also observable with electromagnetic telescopes, providing an opportunity for multimessenger astrophysics. There are a large number of candidate supermassive binary black holes based on, e.g., periodic variations in AGN light curves. We studied how electromagnetic observations can be used to improve gravitational wave searches, and showed that incorporating information about the sky location from electromagnetic observations can help us detect gravitational waves from that source.

Optimizing a pulsar timing array. The goal of this work is to develop observing strategies for pulsar timing arrays to optimize the sensitivity to individual supermassive binary black holes. Specifically, we want to understand how the number of pulsars, their timing precision, the observing cadence, and their sky locations all affect the sensitivity. Previous work has suggested that high-cadence observations improve the sensitivity to individual supermassive binary black holes, and that sensitivity is improved by observing pulsars close to the gravitational wave source.
